instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Not seeing battery
threads.message:
The mac will run on the battery if it is replaced with new one. When the charger is plugged in the charger will turn from green to orange. When the mac boots the battery icon is shown as an X. <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> has been replaced as I see that Louis had this issue and replacing this ic solved the problem. This hasnt fixed the problem in my case. <RESISTOR>R5381</RESISTOR> measures 2.010 <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR> measures 1.984 . <RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR> measures 10.00 . Pin 6 to 9 = 10.00 .

Battery connector diode measurements :
red to ground

1 - ol
2 - ol
3 - ol
4 - 0.468
5 - 0.466
6 - ol
7 - 0.00
8 - 0.00
9 - 0.00

Battery connector diode measurements :
ground to ground

1 - 0.900 then ol
2 - 0.900 then ol
3 - 0.900 then ol
4 - 0.945
5 - 0.942
6 - ol
7 - 0.00
8 - 0.00
9 - 0.00

When running on battery <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> is 7.27 volts, when plugged in <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> is 7.51 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Not seeing battery
threads.message: This would be a dead SMC. Need to take one from a donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Not seeing battery
threads.message: Thanks for that, I dont have any donor boards and dont have the time to wait for one to come from china so il inform the customer of the problem and see what they would like to do.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Not seeing battery
threads.message: Was this liquid? You can try a light reflow on the SMC if it was liquid. No need to fully reflow it, just some heat and flux to boil the crap away.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Not seeing battery
threads.message:
Yes I think it was, coke I think,how hot are we talking, like 150c ?

By the way, what on the info I gave you points to the smc being the problem ?, just so I know what to look out for when diagnosing this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Not seeing battery
threads.message: 150C is fine. There is nothing else involved in battery recognition, SMC,ISL 2 pull up resistors and some traces.
